Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story: I stand at the edge of the site, the morning air thick with the smell of concrete and dust. My hard hat feels heavy as the foreman calls everyone over for the daily safety briefing—mandatory, no exceptions. I glance at my watch; two minutes left. My stomach rumbles, reminding me I skipped breakfast, hoping there’d be something kosher at the communal meal after the briefing. But as I peek at the catering table, my heart sinks. None of the dishes have certification, and I know substituting food will be nearly impossible here. My team expects me to be present, focused, and part of the group, especially during these briefings and shared meals. But my faith demands I keep kosher, even if it means standing apart, maybe even offending someone or drawing unwanted attention. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in—my responsibility to my crew, my loyalty to my beliefs. The foreman’s voice grows louder, calling us over. I hesitate, caught between the expectations of my team and the demands of my faith, unsure which part of myself I’ll have to set aside.
